WRITING.TITLE: I'm in a union job, and I despise the union side
WRITING.TEXT: To be clear, it's not without it's merits. Pay, benefits, big safety net vs management/corporate. But that's where it ends, and it's becoming more and more frustrating. I have found that the union safety net is extremely good at making poor workers feel entitled and safe, thus allowing them to continue to be poor workers. It creates a divide between workers who want to do the bare minimum, and those who want to come in and actually put in a solid effort. The seniority games are ridiculous, and workers know and play that game to the point of literally screwing the next man down. Hard work, consistent high quality results, above and beyond effort mean NOTHING. But since guy A has worked here longer, it means everything even though he's a total dirtbag worker. Guys sleeping on the job and the company can't even fire them because of the union. Oh, but then the union representation. Some are absolutely clueless. Some play the status quo game with the corporate guys simply to not make waves in an effort to keep themselves in their union hall position. Bargaining committees that do anything but bargain when the union and workers have the upper hand. And the list goes on and on. Granted, this is my first and only experience being a union member, and it's only a few years old at that (my experience), but jeez. From what I've seen, the unions of today pale in existence of the unions of lore, where the laborers were actually able to take a stand for themselves.

WRITING.TITLE: Given The Choice -- Reuse X58 Computer or go full Rack (PE R510)
WRITING.TEXT: So, I run a plex server at home, on what originally began as a dedicated HTPC consisting of a mini-itx setup with an AMD a4-5400. Needless to say, transcoding is not one of it's finer points. And I've also noticed that multiple streams don't play nicely on it. So I could go two ways. One would be to pick up a used R510 with an H700 already in it, stuff it with drives, and drop the sledgehammer for a server. The other way, cheaper by far, would be to reuse the X58 computer that currently sits idle most of the time not even powered on. It's an ASUS Rampage III Gene and I7-950 though I'd likely upgrade the processor to a Xeon X5680 (cost/price balance). I could pick up an H700 cheap enough on ebay, couple of sas to sata breakout cables on amazon, and run up to 8 hard drives on it. Con is ram limitations and single processor vs dual in the R510. Pro is simplicity (already running WIn7), familiarity, and no need for a rack, etc. Which way, if you had the choice, would you go and why?

WRITING.TITLE: That was surprisingly easy......
WRITING.TEXT: So making a home brew server, mainly for running as a plex server and storage of all my video files. Had an old X58 Intel setup sitting around (was the kids computer for gaming as it was semi-robust and had a XFX 7970 in it) but decided to re appropriate it after one to many hard shutdowns from the kids screwed the boot drive. As it sat, specs are: I7-950 Hper 212 Evo CPU cooler Rampage III Gene motherboard Samsung 4gb x 3 of that super overclockable low profile ram 1TB Samsung Spinpoint hard drive XFX Double D 7970 OC NZXT H2 Classic case with custom window Nothing spectacular. But today I got in and fired up a Dell PERC H700 raid card. Literally NO issues at all. Recognized on first boot, though I did mask pins 5 and 6 for the SMBus compatibility issue. Had a couple of old 64 GB Sata II SSD's sitting around, so hooked them up. After installing the Dell drivers, and latest LSI Megaraid Storage manager, I have full control. Set them to RAID 0 and after tinkering with the settings was seeing a little over 700 MB read and about 525 MB write speeds via Atto and Crystal Disk Mark. Pretty pleased about. Those drives aren't staying though. Going to move to a 512gb boot drive and several 3 or 4 TB drives for all the data. Pretty pleased with how easy this was to configure and manage. TL:DR -- Old X58 Intel Setup turned into server with H700 and went off without a hitch.

WRITING.TITLE: 2012 Gen 2 Passat Auto "Fix" Completed Monday 6/5 -- Road Trip 6-8 through 6-11 -- Results
WRITING.TEXT: Fix was completed on Monday. Only drove the car about 3 miles home from the dealership, and it was immediately apparent it drove differently. More throttle needed, hanging before shifts, staying in gear longer. Didn't drive it again until Wednesday night going to work (and that was a wash due to an accident and complete gridlock the entire way there). Left thursday morning from work in Fort Wayne IN for southern NJ. Trip there I was coaxing it as best I could. No A/C, windows up, no cruise, working with any inclines or declines, speed held to 60-65 for 95% of the time. Trip out was 645 miles, and the last 50 was philly highway rush hour. Did some driving on Friday, all highway, no stop and go, again, being VERY mindful of economy. Filled up at 716 miles with 15.124 gallons, BUT, being filled up in NJ this morning, I couldn't pump it myself and the attendant didn't get me topped up all the way. Calculates to 47.34 but I think it could have taken more. Fuel light was NOT on, still had a bit of needle room on the gauge between the needle and red even. Route taken: 30-71-76-80-322-76 (PA/TPK) through Philly where it turns into 42 in NJ. Going home today, trip was same route, only backwards, with one spot I took an alternate highway vs. rural detour which made it a little longer. 658 miles when I pulled into my garage and I'm right on hitting the red, 80 to empty showing. Trip home use a little cruise due to some knee pain, A/C was used, had some wind in OH, and speed was mostly 65-70. Using the GPS in the Nav, crossing PA there were some pretty good elevation swings, but after hitting harrisburg, it was only about 200-300 feet at a time, and once in Ohio leveled out with never more than about a 100 foot elevation change. I figure this tank is only 42-43 MPG. Using the trip fuel economy average, going out I never got above 49.2 MPG. Coming home, I hit 47.1 early on and that was it. Normally after an hour or two on the highway, before I was easily in the 50's. Just running around my local area (runs up to Michigan, Chicago area, etc.....highway driving locally) I've pushed MANY tanks in excess of 800 miles with a solid mix of city thrown in. Now it seems I'll be lucky to see that with exclusive highway mileage. My normal work commute is mostly highway, but deals with a bit of early drive stop and go traffic going in during the afternoon rush. I'd still normally pull around 700 miles per tank give or take even using the A/C and what not. I absolutely do NOT forsee that happening now. I don't like accelerating from a stop now. It hangs in gear too long, slow shifts with the flare, and is just irritating to the point that I am using auto stick to upshift during acceleration. My muscle memory is telling me that I'm using FAR more throttle to get it moving, keep it moving, and to maintain speed. I drive with a light foot and when maintaining speed I used to be able to lightly flare the pedal and hold it. Now, if I try that, the car literally tries to decel, I can feel it pitching me forward, and I have to throw heavier on the pedal just to hold speed. VW and the EPA are NUTS thinking a 1 mpg impact is all that's happening. I have lost a LOT more than that, to the point where I'm questioning if the car was even flashed with the right tune because of it's economy and driving characteristics now. I'm going to look into options for returning to the stock tunes from before or aftermarket tunes and the likelihood of those being looked at if something needs servicing under warranty. I came to expect a certain fuel economy out of the car, and 1MPG would have been acceptable, that's only a less than 20 mile per tank difference. The impact I'm seeing here is more like a ~100 mile per tank difference (if this trip was before I had the fix, I have no doubts that the first tank I'd have coaxed up to close to 900 miles based off of previous partial tank trips I've done), or roughly 5-7 MPG depending on conditions. Yes, it still seems to be meeting the "EPA estimates" for economy of 30/40, but realistically, it's not in the ball park for what it used to be.

Some sites fast, some sites slow
WRITING.TEXT: This is a development as of just a couple days ago. My internet has been rock solid, no problems at all. Suddenly, with no indicators, a couple days ago specific websites began to load VERY slow, if at all. These are sites I frequent regularly, remain logged in to, etc. Other sites there is no change and everything is as it should be. I have so far rebooted/restarted my modem (Arris SB6184), router (Netgear R6300 V1), PiHole DNS adblocker (running in a VM from my server), and computer. Verified its network based because I have a server and a laptop (wired and wireless respectively) all of which experienced the exact same problems on the exact same websites, no discrepancies. If I tether my phone (Verizon) to my laptop, I can access the sites perfectly fine. Have also done an ipconfig release and renew. DNS is manually set to my PiHole server with Google DNS as backup, and no change was noted when resetting to automatically acquire DNS from ISP. I'm pretty convinced it's from Comcasts end at this point, but I'm not sure how I should address it with them. Thought I'd see if anyone here has any ideas on the situation? *edit, spelling, I hate my autocorrect*

WRITING.TITLE: Stay Classy, Fort Wayne......

How long to burn oil out of exhaust
WRITING.TEXT: Just finished up putting a new turbo on a 2005 Golf GLS TDI (VNT-17 with tune). Stock turbo went and it was pouring oil out the exhaust. I cleaned ALL intake pipes, intercooler, and charge pipes while I had it apart. Started it up, and just a little smoking at idle. Barely anything. Leak checked good, topped off oil (did an oil change, wasn't level, so didn't have it topped up yet). Took it for a drive around my neighborhood, and left a thick trail of oil 3/4 of the way around, and about halfway around it started building up some head and started smoking....badly. So bad that it was unsafe because it would have completely blinded people behind me. Obviously the exhaust had quite a bit of oil in it. I tried another short drive with the same result also. Oil level on motor is NOT dropping that I can tell, so I don't think it's the new turbo leaking or anything. Just wondering how long I'm going to have to expect this smoking before it'll clear. Anyone with a similar experience?

Just a little vent/self reflection all wrapped up.....
WRITING.TEXT: This is gonna be long so be forewarned. This is motivated partly by some self reflection and partly by the current political environment, so infer as you wish. People ask me why I work as hard as I do. I always try to go above and beyond. It's in my programming. Why do I come in on overtime when the company (by perception, I try to keep things in perspective) and Union treat us worker like crap. Why I am always go go go. Simple put, because I've learned there's no getting ahead unless you work for it. Things just don't come free and there's certainly no free rides unless you're one of a VERY privileged few. I'm on the tail end of a 3 day weekend as scheduled from work. This entire weekend was spent doing things making me get ahead. From scavenging parts for our vehicle we are getting ready to sell (little things we've let go), to swapping all mounts and a clutch on our "new" vehicle we bought as an economical move, I stayed busy with very little down time. Sure I spent some family time, played with the kids, chilled with a good friend who helped me wrench, but most of my time was spent working, doing something, being productive. Even now, I'm working on cleaning and organizing my garage to work better for me, to be more efficient, and taking a break to organize my thoughts here. Anyway..... I've pondered myself why I rarely say no to extra time at work. I've pondered why I feel guilty if I completely waste a day doing nothing productive at all. As I stepped out of my garage for some cool night air this night, I glanced inside my house through my windows, some dark, some lit. THAT is why. My family, comfortable inside, peacefully at rest feeling safe, happy. One of our cats carefully watching me from a window, happy and fat. I saw into my office, where I have pictures of my "Iconic American Sports car" on the wall from when I first owned it, having sold it during hard times and bought it back after regaining my feet. That made it hit home as trite and materialistic as it sounds. I had it VERY well back about 7 years ago, and I lost almost all of it but my family, and nearly lost them in the process. Hard work, perseverance, and perhaps a little luck and divine intervention, and I am doing better than I ever had. But it didn't come free. I had to work and I continue to work. I had to make sacrifices. And I will continue to work and make sacrifices for the betterment of my family and myself. Point is, the world doesn't give you things for free, and the world certainly isn't fair. The world doesn't care if you're offended, or about your feelings. You are what you make of yourself, plain and simple. Nobody is holding you down but you. People words won't stop you from succeeding. Seven years ago, at a lowest of the low points anyone could experience, I could have rolled over and given up, but I pressed on, and though it took some struggles, trials, and truly hard times, I overcame. You can too. Don't let anyone tell you you're not good enough or you can't. I have a very dark mark following me and not a single day goes by that I don't regret past decisions I made, but you can't dwell on it, you must learn from your past and move forward. You can't erase your history and expect everything to improve. You must take steps to make those improvements on your own, as no one will do it for you. History is history, you cannot run from nor hide from it,you can only learn and do better than before. So here I sit, about to get back to it. Looking from the outside in (being eaten by mosquitoes, freaking yaay), reflecting on roads traveled in the past, heeding lessons learned, and being grateful for where i am and what I have, and what lies before me. Perhaps you should too. Perhaps you should stop dwelling on the past, look at what you have, how you can improve, and what you need to do in order to make those improvements. I'm tired of all the rhetoric, tired of all the "something for nothing mentalities." You and only you are responsible for what you make of yourself, I am a living testament to that. Be strong, hold faith in nothing but yourself and those you hold dear, and keep trying, overcoming, and moving forward.

WRITING.TITLE: Linux Noob, Dual Boot with separate drives and an additional motherboard RAID 1 Array......
WRITING.TEXT: Getting tired of Windows 10, and figured I'd at least give Linux a run. Have Win 10 on a Samsung 950 Pro M.2 NVME drive, and installed Linux Mint 18 on a spare SATA II AData 64gb SSD I had laying around. Went through some growing pains, but after finding an obscure setting in my BIOS I was able to set the spare drive as the main boot drive (Thanks for making it difficult EVGA) and GRUB2 picked up my WIndows boot loader, and I can choose freely between OS's on boot (just have normal issue of no NIC connectivity in Linux if I warm swap from Windows....I MUST do a power removed shutdown to get the NIC in Linux). ANYWAY.......... I run a RAID1 array of 2x 3TB hard drives as my data drives for backups of photo's, video's, run my transcoding through them, music, etc. I'm having trouble getting Linux to see these drives as a RAID array and not single drives. Using DMRAID -R in a terminal, I get the following: /dev/sdc: isw, "isw_bgbjjidfed", GROUP, ok, 5860533166 sectors, data@ 0 /dev/sdb: isw, "isw_bgbjjidfed", GROUP, ok, 5860533166 sectors, data@ 0 But.......they don't act like a RAID 1 array. I trial moved an item to one drive, and it was not copied to the other. I'm looking for guidance on how to fix this. Motherboard is an EVGA Micro2 X99, and Processor is a Intel I7 5820K if that's needed. I'm tempted to scrap the Linux experiment if I can't get this Raid Array showing properly as I have a LOT of family data backed up to it and need to ensure things stay copied to a second drive. *edit for formatting

Parental type controls
WRITING.TEXT: I'm in the market for a Mesh type wifi system. I keep coming back to the Orbi because it has a great feature set and proven track record. I currently have an R6300 router and am familiar with the Netgear interface, which is the cause of my concerns. Are the parental controls and internet access management any better on the Orbi than my old R6300? I have two school age kids and had actually put DD-WRT on my R6300 so I could assign quiet times to their connected devices, shut off at a moment's notice should the need arises, etc. With the Netgear interface it seemed that I had to turn the network off then add exceptions for anything I wanted to connect. Very counterintuitive to me. Has this changed? This is a major factor iny purchase as it's something I need to have without relying on a 3rd party app or the like.

WRITING.TITLE: Nearly a week with an Orbi RBK53 now........
WRITING.TEXT: And I've been VERY impressed with it. I was at the point where it was this or start stringing ethernet cables around (i.e. through) the house and basement and going to a full Ubiquiti router/switch/AP setup. My ONLY gripe is that due to positioning, sometimes my wifi devices hit the wrong router due to signal coming through. I'm in a two story 3200SF house on a basement (which isn't being used or factored in). Orbi router sits in my office at the front center of the house, one AP is in the great room on the same floor at the rear left of the house, the other AP is in the master bedroom at the top right of the house. Everything is close enough that there is some overlap which I expected, but can be a nuisance. For instance, my Xbox in my bedroom, though sitting a foot away from an AP, kept picking up my main router downstairs. Using ethernet on this fixed it no problemo. The dedicated backhaul channel really does it's job well, and I'm glad I went with this over the other mesh system I was contemplating (Amplifi HD) due to this capability. Got it installed, everything worked out great. Got some DHCP reservations set so there's no confusion, and let the wifi devices eat. Essentially, anywhere in my house now I'm getting throughput as if I was wired to the main router. VERY impressive to say the least. Have had zero issues yet other than some IP conflicts and some preset info issues (DHCP reservation in router combatting with static IP setting on device from previous setup causing latency for example). Haven't messed with circle yet, but found that using the phone app I can at will block devices internet access, which is exactly what my wife and I wanted. For the $400, this was WELL worth the investment. If it's long term stability holds up, I'll be even more pleased with it.

Indiana -- Stolen Vehicle Recovery from Canada....with a twist.
WRITING.TEXT: Ok, this is weird. But follow along...... Sold a Chrysler Pacifica on August 25th last year. Like 3-4 days later, it was stolen from the new owner who never did the title/registration transfer, nor did he report it stolen to the police (for reasons that later became obvious as he had a warrant he got picked up on anyway). Out of my hands, but I tried to help where I could as the title with my identifiable information was IN the vehicle when stolen. Fast forward to last week. Get a call from Ontario of all places. Some customs official tracked me down, the Pacifica is in impound in Canada and apparently has been since early September. Thieves got hemmed up by the law there. Ok, cool, I give him the new owners info. Wash my hands of it again. Fast forward to today. Gentleman in Canada calls back. They talked to FWPD, and since the title was never transferred, I am still the registered legal owner. They won't work with anyone but me since it's legally still my vehicle. So looks like I'm going to Canada to pick up the Pacifica I sold. But wait......there's more. The guy I sold it to. His phone isn't accepting calls, nor is it accepting texts. His mother had called me while he was in jail last fall asking about the Pacifica (sweet lady), so I went through my phone records and spoke to her today. She said she randomly hears from her son and doesn't have a direct point of contact for him as of now either. She made it seem like he may or may not be in contact with me. So now I'm left in a conundrum. TECHNICALLY (and morally), it's not my vehicle. LEGALLY, it still is per the law and title/registration. The ONLY person customs in Canada is going to release it to is me because my name is on the title still. So obviously I'm going to pick it up. Then beckons the question......how long do I sit on it for before removing it from my possession if I don't hear from the guy? I can't just drop it off to his mother because she's in Montana. He travels all over the place (circus guy). Like what are my legal obligations here? He paid for the vehicle, and I will do my due diligence to get him the vehicle back after picking it up, but am I bound by a timeframe to do so? If I don't hear from the guy after six months and it's sitting idle outside my house, is it reasonable/legal to expect me to keep sitting on it? I'm just not sure how to proceed after picking it up given the high likelihood I won't ever be contacted by the guy. Even his mother said if it turns into a couple of months just sell it to someone else. I don't want to end up in a lawsuit or something over this when I'm going to go out of my way (3.5 hour one way trip to pick up) to get the vehicle back and try to help.

WRITING.TITLE: All right R/Corvette people......what have you owned? What have you driven? What is your favorite?
WRITING.TEXT: Just seeing what makes people tick. I've personally only owned one Corvette.......but twice. My twin turbo modded 1999 Nassau Blue C5 Coupe. Owned it from May 2006 to November 2010, then repurchased it from the person I sold it to in May of 2015 and will never let it go again. I've been behind the wheel of a couple others, a 1995 LT1 M6 a LONG time ago, a 1998 A4 Coupe a couple months before I originally bought my 99, a 78 while working as an auto tech (it came in for a braking pull, found a cracked front cradle of all things), and very late last year got behind the wheel of a friends 2016 ZO6. I've sat in or worked on plenty of others over the years. Hate to say it but I never envision owning a C7 (though I LOVE the ZR1). Riding in it I couldn't keep my right knee out of the dash. Driving it I couldn't keep my right shin out of the dash. Just felt it was VERY small inside compared to my C5. I can't shake how it felt driving the LT1 C4 though. WRITING.TITLE: Well past the point of "tinkering" now.......

WRITING.TEXT: Seems odd to have a low mileage car need seat covers replaced. As far as issues, make sure the ABS, Active Handling, and Traction Control systems aren't throwing any codes. The 97-00 C5's aren't supported anymore, and if your ABS module goes out, IF you can find one, you're going to pay dearly. Same for the Steering Wheel Position Sensor. You CAN upgrade to the 2001-2004 stuff but there's quite a bit of work involved. The Cluster will have the connection for the HUD, but you'll need to piece together a kit. I'd recommend find a painted solid roof and forget the acrylic one. It's like an acoustic amplifier. I hated mine when I bought the car and ended up selling it. Working on the C5 is like any other car. I'm knee deep in my motor right now for some upgrades. Be aware of the driveline. If you don't know, the Clutch/flexplate is on the back of the motor, but the trans is connected to the diff in the back, everything connected by a torque tube with the driveshaft riding inside it. Clutch jobs are a task, and clutch pedal issues abound. Keep your fluid clean and fresh.
Well played. Have an upvote.

Hmmmm......that's interesting. That's actually pretty nice that they take care of things like that. Sounds like a worthy place. Pull the codes. You can do it without a scanner using the DIC: gt; 1. Turn your key to the "ON" position, but do not start the engine. gt; 2. Clear any present messages by pressing the RESET button. gt; 3. Hold the OPTIONS button down, and press the FUEL button 4 times. (This will get you into the "codes" section of the DIC. gt; 4. The computer will automatically display all the codes your car has created. It will cycle through each code every 3 seconds. (Have a pen and paper handy to write down the codes) gt; Note: Any code that ends in an "H" is a history code (something that has occurred in the past, but is not reporting as an error currently.) gt; 5. Once the computer has finished going through all of its codes, press RESET to enter Manual Configuration mode. It should start with a module and show "NO CODES" or "# Codes." gt; 6. To optionally reset codes once in manual mode, press and hold RESET until is displays "NO CODES." gt; 7. Press OPTIONS to go into the next module (ie, from PCM, or Powertrain Control Module, to TCS, or Traction Control System.) gt; 8. Repeat Step 6 until you have reset all the codes in all the computer modules. gt; Note: Only reset the codes if you want to- it is not necessary to reset them every time you pull the codes. gt; 9. When finished, simply take your key out of the ignition. As far as the top, they may not be adding anything to the painted tops. Mine is a factory piece (when I bought the car from the original owner he had both tops) and it was padded and cloth covered on the inside from GM. I personally haven't found anything I can't do on my car on jacks and stands. And I've had my low mount twin turbo kit in and out, driveline in and out, done long tube headers in and out, Motor out and back in, etc. A lift would DEFINITELY make life easier, but there's really nothing you can't do on stands with a couple of jacks. Someone else mentioned the balancer issues. This is a GM Gen III+ issue not just C5's. And when they go, it's random. I replaced the one in my car with an SLP back in 2006 due to separation at 55K miles of the stock piece. Watch it while it's running before you buy the car and see if it's wobbling or you're getting belt chirping. And just so you're absolutely aware, you have to pull the steering rack to do the job. It's kind of a pain because you have to unbolt then pull out through the drivers side wheel well. And generally, you have to loosen the cradle and pry the opening open a little wider to facilitate (yes, I've done this a few times, lol). Typical 1/2" torque wrench will go to 250 ft/lbs or so. I'd recommend an aftermarket ARP bolt to replace the stocker, they're reusable and don't require the same torque sequence (stock is torque to yield so you have to degree turn stretch the bolt). The car you're looking at isn't an FRC is it? If it is, check for leaks around the windows and down the pillars. *edit - formatting*

WRITING.TITLE: B7, C7, etc.......playable file formats via USB
WRITING.TEXT: Essentially the OLED is the only 4K device in my house (for now). I run a plex server, but don't see a need for 4K movies to be stored on it. I want to run a external drive direct to the OLED to keep 4K movies stores. What I'm NOT finding documentation on is the acceptable video and audio formats that the TV will interpret and play. Anyone have this info?

Two fold. Saving server space for one since there's only the one 4K TV in the house. That and seems there's a lot of direct stream issues when moving the file through an XBox or the like, and most of the time it gets transcoded down to 1080 anyway by what I've been reading. On a positive note, answered my own question. The B7A (and I'm assuming the rest) will play a 4K MKV format with 7.1 or 5.1 off an NTFS formatted external drive with ZERO issues. I just ripped and played Wonder Woman in all of it's 4K glory without a hitch.
Looks clean! I like the front corner lights. Goes with the rest of the car very nicely!

How are you direct playing the 4k content without transcoding? What device are you using? What format is your media in? Curious because if I don't need to run an external I won't, I can always expand the array on my server.

I don't know if I can do a direct link to a forum here, so I'll say google search "MakeMKV 4K" and the first result should be an AVSforum link. In a nutshell, you'll need a Ultra HD friendly drive. This is important because Ultra HD Compatible drives have the proper firmware to NOT bypass the AACS 2.0 copy protection. The forum link has a list. You'll need a ripping program. MakeMKV I've used for YEARS and it's free in beta (or $50 to puchase ahead of the game). Excellent program. Redfox is another, and there are others out there. Next step is optional, as you can rip to a MKV format with 7.1 or 5.1 or even stereo audio (whatever options you're presented with) as well as subtitles. But a 4K movie is about 55-65 GB per movie. Normal 1080 Blu Ray's are anywhere from 6 to 40 GB depending on how much CGI and what not is involved. You can use these files directly, or use a program to compress, hardcode subtitles, etc. Handbrake is that program. Free, stable, powerful. I have NOT tried encoding a 4K to compress the file size yet, but most of my 1080 Blu Ray library sits at 6-12GB per movie with some heavy CGI movies (think Transformers) coming in at 15-20 GB. I keep my quality on the high end though. Do some searching and reading, there's tons of guides, but the above is what has worked for me since I started digitizing my collection in 2012.

I won't be getting another streaming device, so it'll probably be a external drive setup then due to the fact that the built in Web OS Plex app won't decode my 7.1 encodes (DTS HD-MA pass through) so I get no audio.

It won't do mine with the web os app. As I said I did a DTS HD-MA passthrough and I get nothing. Fire up the Xbox and it's app and I get audio. This is pushing audio through ARC to a Klipsch RSB-11. Not sure how that's false but that's what's happening. But just direct played Wonder Woman from the USB last night with 7.1 audio and it ran fine.

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone familiar with the H700 RAID card.......Question concerning Port Expanders
WRITING.TEXT: So I have a "server" running in a case and it's FULL of hard drives. Eight on the H700 to be exact, so the SAS to SATA breakout cables are full and on both ports. I'm looking at a very high potential to need to expand due to acquiring the ability to rip my 4K movies finally. I know I can migrate the H700 over to a new motherboard and not lose my VD's, but what I need to know is if I can move one of the VD's off the H700 itself and on to a port expander card without losing the VD config and data on those drives? Essentially unplug from the H700, plug the Expander card into the H700, then the 4 way SATA breakout cable into a port on the expander.

WRITING.TITLE: Sweet WHAT?

WRITING.TEXT: I get that, but will it see the drives in the same VD configuration they're in now with no data loss if I move them from the H700 to the expander card. I.E. if I add the expander, and move the drives to it, will the H700 still see them as if they were still connected directly and subsequently leave the virtual disc intact?

Either car is going to be pretty admirable in the performance arena. The C5Z is capable of running in the high 11's in the 1320 bone stock with a solid good driver and good air. The C6 Auto or stick won't be dark behind. Something to consider also if you ever plan to mod the car. Wheel options for the C6 are vastly greater than for the C5 when larger aftermarket brakes are concerned. Due to the C5's fender line it's difficult to get a wheel with the right offset to clear something like a C6Z brake caliper. The C6's fenderlines allow for better offsets and a wider variety (plus having the ability to bolt on the C6Z flares fenders helps a lot too). I'm not saying the C5 is a bad car at all. I own one and love it. But it's dated, build quality is the epitome of late 90's GM manufacturing, and the C6 was a positive evolutionary step forward. I think you'd be happy in either one.

Timing belt interval on the 2012's (I have a 2012 Passat) is 130K.

I bought my 2012 Passat at 92K miles back in early September 2015 (literally days before DG dropped). It now has 135K and climbing. Has been largely trouble free. Bought it knowing it had an exhaust flap needing fixed under warranty. Had the AdBlue heater done under warranty (120K). Had a single temp sensor in the intercooler go bad (replaced under the DG warranty). Only incident that has cost me out of pocket was where the main fuel feed line spontaneously separated and left me stranded briefly. Been a really solid reliable car to date overall. Timing belt interval on the 2012's is 130K per dealer data sheets. It's about a $750-900 job (indy vs dealer pricing) when it comes due so be prepared for that. If it's a car that's been fixed under the dieselgate program, then it's going to have a 4/52K warranty (was 4/48K but I just received a mailer extending that an extra 4K miles) on pretty much ANYTHING related to the induction/fueling/exhaust/emissions system. DSG is a 40K interval. If there are no service records I'd say service it just for precautionary measures. If the car is clean and well taken care of I'd have zero hesitation on buying one even at 150K miles.

I drive around 25 highway miles a day to work, and regularly get 700+ miles on a tank of fuel from my 2012 Passat TDI, averaging around 42-44MPG mixed. Last fall we bought my wife a 2015 Golf Sportwagen TDI and her driving is almost exclusively in town short trips, and she only gets about 30-32 MPG running around town. Hindsight we should have bought her a hybrid of some sorts. With your commute, you'll probably do well in the TDI, and that's a pretty good price for the miles on the car.

I don't think there's any golden ticket for doing this. My wife has been a SAHM since we relocated in 2013. Lack of debt is VERY key. You simply have to make enough to support everything on the one income. Looking at your situation, I don't see it as a feasible move quite yet for you with the numbers you've given. If your wife were to continue working, what would her net gain to the monthly income be AFTER factoring in child care costs? Does your wife have the capability to work from home with her current job (there ARE work from home jobs out there but they're hard to come by). Do you have any upward mobility in your job, possibilities of moving to a more lucrative job or relocating to a lower cost of living area?

I see. Best advice from my limited perspective.....have her go back to work until you can knock the monthly bills down. Set yourself up for a strong start on the single income rather than giving it a go from an upside down position. About your job.....are you 100% from home or is there an office you have to go in to on occasion? Would a move to the lower cost suburbs be out of the question, or even farther out into a rural area and you just deal with a longer drive if you have to show up somewhere?

WRITING.TITLE: Hey LG, I don't believe this is how multi year discounts are supposed to work....

WRITING.TEXT: Didn't know where else to put this, relevant to OLED as I received it with regards to one of my (I have two OLED's) TV's I purchased earlier this year. Somehow.....the math seems.....off.......

Check at Monoprice. I've been using their mounts for years now (installed my first one, a full articulating job that I literally hung myself off of back in 2009, only cost $45 at the time). Get a mount with a full back frame, not one of the ones where the cross bars are in two pieces. Those always shift and are a pain. Currently have my 65" OLED on [this](https://www.monoprice.com/product?c_id=109 amp;cp_id=10828 amp;cs_id=1082822 amp;p_id=12278 amp;seq=1 amp;format=2) mount; I did modify the support bars for the 400x300 VESA on the OLED. There are other options available that are no modification necessary. My advice: ALWAYS get the main mount installed (with 4 locally purchased good lag bolts) into STUDS. NEVER try installing into drywall, I don't care what kind of device you're using to put the bolt into. Definitely need a level. Pre-drill for the lag bolts, you run far less risk of blowing out a stud if you're close to an edge. Stud finder also...... I install the main bracket starting with the first hole, then level off of that. Usually get a 0 #176; level without issue that way. Top right, then top left, then finish up with the two on the bottom. Also, don't forget when setting the height to compensate for the offset of the VESA on the TV. You've got some wiggle room vertically on the hangers for the mount, but only so much. If you don't get the bracket in a good spot, you may find your TV is too high or low.

All the C4's were fuel injected. STAY AWAY from the 1984 Crossfire models. Just. Don't. The Tuned Port 350 available from 1985-1991 was a good dependable motor, great low end torque, but ran out of steam pretty quick. The LT1 introduced in 1992 is what's known as the Gen II Small Block Chevy, and is a pretty big leap up from the TPI motors. In 1996 you could also get a C4 with the further enhanced LT4 motor rated at 330 HP. For a REAL kick in the pants, for about $15-25K you can hop into a 1990-1995 LT5 equipped C4 ZR1 Corvette rated at anywhere from 375-405 HP. GREAT cars those ZR1's. Also, I'd say stay away from Manual Trans cars if they're pre-1989. The Nash 4+3 isn't a solid unit. The ZF6 Six Speed trans introduced in 89 is a VERY solid transmission (I like driving it better than the TR6060 in my C5).

C5's have a VERY hard clear coat. This has been proven over and over. It takes some serious work to polish them out. If yours is scratching easily, something is amiss......

Spend some time on the Corvette Forum. You'll find that hard clear coat is the norm on the C5. I can personally attest to that as I've done polishing work on more than a few and every one of them took some pretty aggressive compounds to even make a dent in any swirling, scratches, etc. Don't mistake scratching to mean soft clear coat. If your microfiber towel has ANY kind of abrasive in it, is dirty, etc, it can and will put scratches into any clear coat. The true test comes into play when you go to polish those imperfections out.

WRITING.TITLE: Ugh......that feeling when your server suddenly isnt online.......
WRITING.TEXT: And you go check your server and find your boot drive has decided to remove itself from service. Dead. Stupid me, I had no backup image to reinstall to a new drive. That said......how much pain am I in for trying to get Plex all lined up again. Expecting some downloading to get all the images back, having to set up my collections again, etc. Will I be able to simply install and log in again with the same server name? Good news is all the media is safe behind a PERC H700. Other good news is I don't have to worry about the old spinner drive anymore and am replacing it with a 1tb SSD now. Boy was I ticked when I found this all out after 10pm last night.

I realize this, and am comfortable with the parity offered via the RAID to be enough to cover me. The SSD is simple just to improve on the old spinner that just died, and lower the heat in the drive way where it's located (top of box hot swap bad because all internal drive bays are full).

I'll add some more info. I'm not a Dev by any means, and this was a Windows install so unfortunately a lot of suggestions are moot, but sincerely appreciated. This was kind of self induced. The boot drive that died was sketchy and I got lazy in spending the money to replace it and it bit me. C'est la vie Thank you everyone for the suggestions. I'm picking up a new 1tb SSD on the way home from work and will hopefully get it up and running again this evening. I'd been binging Roadkill before bed and am going through withdrawals.

UPDATE: I cheaped out and got a 500GB SSD instead of the 1TB. I'll just have to be a little more proactive on cleaning out the downloaded torrent files. Drive installed, took a clean Win7 installation, and PMS is currently chugging away downloading metadata for my 400+ movies before it's going to import my TV shows back in. Best news, the H700 proved worth it's weight in gold. All both virtual drives were untouched, unharmed, and no data was lost. Now....getting my Sonarr back up and running and playing nice with BTN........that was painful the first time and it's been a while. Expecting more pain there, lol.

I considered it, but there's a couple of issues. WRITING.TITLE: Dirty little secret.........or maybe not. But I found it interesting
WRITING.TEXT: Starting a timing belt job on my 2012 Passat CKRA motor today. I spent a LONG time debating over what timing belt kit to go with. There's lots of options out there, and if you're still a forum guy like I am, there's LOTS of opinions on using supporting vendors. I'm all for supporting the vendors that pay the forum bill, within reason. Such as this current situation. IDParts -- $300 for the kit, Contintech belt DieselGeek -- $297 for the kit, Gates belt, Hepu WP with steel impeller CascadeGerman -- $350 for the kit, Contitech Belt etc. Around $300 everywhere. RockAuto -- $220, Continental Contitech kit The difference? Two of the three above (Dieselgeek is the odd man out) include new bolts for the engine mount, which you do NOT have to remove. Certainly not $80 worth of bolts. Now for the meat of this. EVERY. LAST. KIT. uses the exact same Litens Timing Tensioner and INA rollers which is OEM stuff. The OEM belt on the car is a Contitech, so again, all but dieselgeek are using the OEM belt (I have ZERO problems and would have preferred the GATES, but OEM is good enough for me). DieselGeek is the only one using a metal impeller water pump, but I'm not exactly sure it's necessary (I *think* the OEM pump is a composite impeller also). The belt in the Contitech kit I bought carries a 120K mile guarantee (though I expect some company push back because I am not a shop, just a former tech, and they'll try to nullify the guarantee) also. Point is, while there are some respected vendors out there for these TDI parts, IDParts at the top of the list (their service kits are worth their weight in gold, I'm waiting on two 40K kits for both my cars to show up), dig around if you like to be cost effective. Odds are you'll end up with the exact same parts and save a healthy chunk in the process.

So I split the job up over two days, just because I had two days off and didn't feel like ramming through it. Literally had the timing belt fully exposed and ready to be taken off in less than an hour. Last TDI timing belt job I did was on my buddies former car, a 01 Golf with the ALH. This job on the CKRA in my Passat was FAR more simple. Used the Dieselgeek method to replace the tensioner, so I didn't have to remove the motor mount. I only disconnected a single line on top, the long coolant line that goes to the top of the expansion tank. And really, I didn't even have to remove that, I could have worked around it. On the 12-14 Passat's, the only thing you REALLY need to remove and get out of the way is the bracket that sits directly above the motor mount. Two 10mm Triple Square bolts hold it in place. Just free that and loop it around behind the motor with the lines still attached (remove the three hose holder on the top side of the bracket obviously). I didn't break free the cam or pump bolts. Instead, when I installed the timing belt, I started at the bottom of the cam, and went clockwise, so all the slack ended up at the tensioner to begin with. Worked out fine. Everything lined back up once I properly set the tensioner. Good timing for the job too (pun intended). I found my water pump was leaking. As for the parts, ALL the parts in the Continental Contitech kit were a match brand for brand with the OEM stuff on the car EXCEPT for the water pump. The $210 kit from Rock Auto had everything I needed to do the job, and properly, while saving $80ish bucks from one of the Diesel vendors kits. I genuinely think I could do this job in 3 hours, 4 worst case, should I do another.

The 2001+ cars have a couple of major plusses over a 2000 and earlier. That being the EBCM/ABS Pump and the SWPS (Steering Wheel Position Sensor) are no longer made or available on the aftermarket for the early 97-00 cars. The early cars CAN be retrofitted with the later model stuff, but it's a good amount of work. Also, the 01+ cars got a slight hp and tq bump along with the LS6 manifold as standard.

Dealer timing belt service usually runs around $900. I just did mine for about $240 myself on my very similar 2012 Passat TDI.

For your driving......the TDI may not be the best choice. You're going to spend a premium in terms of cost, fuel cost, and if you don't DIY things, maintenance cost. Your 12 mile commute is NOT going to help you realize the advantages of owning a TDI. They NEED solid highway trips to really see the advantage over a gasser. I made the same mistake with my wife's car last year, we bought her a 2015 Sportwagen TDI. All she does it putter around town most of the time with a random road trip we take thrown in. So on a normal tank she'll only see about 350-400 miles out of the tank, usually averaging 32-34 MPG. For comparison sake, my 2012 Passat sees a 25 mile 90% highway commute each way, and I average around 44mpg normally. Both cars I can stretch to 50 or more MPG on a LONG road trip (Passat best was 49.9 and the Sportwagen I've gotten 54 out of for it's best). Point is, with your short commute, the added TDI cost may not be offset by any fueling advantage. You very well may end up on par with gasser car economy. As far as reliability..........do your maintenance on a TDI and you'll find them to be super reliable. I've owned my Passat for 3 years and 50K miles now and I've had one breakdown that was a total random freak thing (fuel line separated) and a couple of minor issues all covered under warranty. We have owned the 15 Sportwagen for nearly a year and haven't had a single issue yet. They're well built, solid, reliable cars. But like any car, they can have problems. People throwing the "unreliable" tag out are simply overreacting.

About $150 or so cheaper, BUT........parts being used are big box store parts and the belt specifically may not carry the same change interval. I went through this back when I was debating paying for mine to get done or not. Dealership uses all VW stuff (mine does at least). Indy shop uses whatever they can get locally for the best deal so they can mark it up and make the most off of it. So I called the big box stores, and NONE of them, even the .... Know How logo guys, could give me a firm answer on what their timing belt change interval was. So I said nope, bought a contitech kit for $210 (it's all the same manufacturer as OEM except the water pump), and went to town.

Apparently reading further and researching something for yourself isn't a task taken lightly and using the terms "likely" and "probably" are now considered to be coming across as hard fact just as posting them to Reddit makes them hard fact. Get over yourselves, lol. I'm not spreading misinformation or anything. I made an assumption based off of having been to Hickam numerous times and what I know about the base. It was wrong and correct information was presented below which I acknowledged. A VERY quick google search shows that I was wrong, and C-17 Fuel Cell Hangar 19 in fact was opened on April 14, 2009. So by demanding I update this you're taking a valuable contribution by another person and relegating it insignificance because now people don't have to look further to see any more info. Round of applause folks. My condolences to tenacious_mucus post. I found it valuable and acknowledged it as such.

Ok, I wasn't sure. Basic bolt on upgrades will get you to the 290-300 RWHP range. Cold Air Intake, Headers, high flow car or off road pipe, and a good cat-back exhaust. Round it out with a 160* thermostat and a tune to put it all together. After that, a cam swap can get you to 350-360 RWHP if you go big enough (bigger custom, or a good old shelf grind like the GM847 or CC306). If it's an automatic, a stall will wake it up at any point. You can do the throttle body coolant bypass without worry. Your throttle body will NEVER freeze up unless you live in Antarctica. As big of an LTx fan as I am, it's a dated limited platform with a couple of nefarious design issues (optispark amiright?). If you drop $10K into a massive top shelf stroked aftermarket headed motor build, you're still only going to end up in the 500 RWHP range. Not saying it's a bad platform, but keep your expectations tempered.
Hate to say it man but you're about 15 years behind the power curve trying to come up with new material like this for the fourth gen platform. Best of luck though.

WRITING.TITLE: Said goodbye to my old man this evening.....

WRITING.TEXT: This guy has been in my life longer than anything else at this point. Got him (and his brother who passed Jan 2016) as kittens back in July of 2001. He had slowly been losing weight over the past few months but showed zero signs of anything going on. Started acting a little off a couple of days ago, then today I'm in my closet getting changed for work and I hear what sounds like a creaky hinge being moved back and forth. It was my buddy and he was working to breathe, lethargic, and obviously in pain all of a sudden. Called work, ran off to the vet, x-ray showed a healthy heart and lungs. But his abdomen.....he had what the vet diagnosed as a slow growing lymphatic tumor that finally got big enough to push on his diaphram and make him have to work to breath right. He was pale, bad circulation, and his temp was way down, and he was probably tired because he probably wasn't able to sleep given the breathing effort. There was really no choice, and I wasn't going to pump him with drugs in order to put off a more painful slow passing. So I gave him all the love I could those final fleeting minutes, told the vet give us a while. He managed to drift into a catnap as I held his head up for a few minutes, and I just sat there bawling and appreciating the time we had together. I held his head in my hands and my forehead to his as he passed. I hope he was telling me the same, as he was purring all the way through. He had a good long life and I'm just happy he let me be part of it.

WRITING.TITLE: These were my boys.........

WRITING.TEXT: Jerry is on the left, Ben is on the right. They were brothers, born in April of 2001 and adopted by me in early July of the same year. Ben passed away on Jan 11, 2016 from renal failure. Jerry passed away two days ago, Oct 10, 2018, from a lymphatic tumor. I adopted them when I was single back in 01. Didn't meet my now wife until about 9 months later. These two and I had a special bond. I was their human, they were my boys. I've had pets all my life and have NEVER experienced a bond with one like I did with these two. And unfortunately, I don't think I'll get to experience that again given any pets now have a house full of humans to enjoy. Perhaps it's for the best, as I'd rather keep the special connection I had to just them. Ben was Mr Inquisitive, and never met a person he didn't like. Always had to perch on the highest point he could get to. Always a talker if you talked to him, and he loved to yowl the night away. Best temperament I've ever seen in a cat too. I only ever saw him hiss once in his entire life. He was all about love. I could tell him come give me a kiss and he'd walk up and give me a head bonk on the face. Jerry was my big boy. He was a big time talker, loved being held, loved sleeping at my side. I already dearly miss waking up and feeling his weight leaning up against me. He wasn't much of a people person, but if he liked you, he let you know it. He adored getting his shoulders scratched, along with the typical head rubs. These guys were something else. Up until now, they have been the one thing that's constantly been in my life, longer than anything else. I miss them both so much. Thanks for listening. I needed to get this out somewhere.

A LONG time ago........probably about 1988 or 1989, I was a latchkey kid and home alone for a couple hours after school. One day I got home and decided to eat an orange. Peeled it, separated it, put it on a plate, and went to the living room. Laid down on the floor in front of the TV and started eating said orange. About halfway through, I have no idea how it happened, but suddenly I could feel this chewed up piece of orange dangling in two places. One side in my esophagus, the other in my windpipe. Every bit of air that was escaping I couldn't get back. I started to freak, then as best I could, internalized to calm down, build up from my core, and exhale all at once. Coughed it right up. To this day that still freaks me out. I was 10 or 11 at the time.

WRITING.TITLE: Thank goodness for pixel refresh
WRITING.TEXT: Had a three day weekend. My kids and I all play fortnite, and Friday night we played for a LONG time. Saturday morning I fire up the 65B7A and the Xbox, and on the green screen I noticed a disturbing dark bar........right where the bright green health bar sits. I had never seen it before after long sessions and was ready to freak out. Ran pixel refresher twice in a row, and it helped a LOT. Did normal activity yesterday, ran again last night after everyone was headed to bed. Fired everything up this morning and it's barely noticeable at all, and only on the green Xbox screen. Haven't picked it out of anything else yet (football Sunday and if it was there I'd notice). What concerns me is the sudden and very obvious retention from that bar. I've swapped the picture setting to game to subdue the color and mitigate any further issues, but I really wish these game makers would make some of these static info bars with user adjustable opacity.

Didn't mean any knock on you man. I posted that having spent a few years as an auto tech. Will it run and drive? Almost certainly. Will it burn oil? WRITING.TITLE: Headset Issues -- I'm old (enough) and confused here.........[Tech]
WRITING.TEXT: So we have four XBox One controllers. One original without a 3.5mm jack, one original with a 3.5mm jack, and two white S controllers. ALL controllers are synced with the "family" Xbox in our living room which my kids use. My oldest was given a Turtle Beach Recon headset for his birthday by a friend. It worked fine.....for a time.......and by "a time" I mean a day....literally. He got a couple hours in, left, came back, and nothing. He was frustrated but got along without. He predominantly uses the white S controllers. Today I started looking into it. I figured it must have been in security settings or something, but everything is fine there. Here's what I found. The headset works FINE with the original remote (black one) with the 3.5mm jack. It does NOT work AT ALL with either of the white S remotes. I disassembled one of the white S remotes and reseated the 3.5mm jack, and still nothing. I tried other headsets (we have a couple of the XBox Chat headsets then I have some headphones with internal mic's also). Same situation. I've tried changing every setting I could find, tried updating the S controller firmware (no dice, says up to date), hard reset on the XBox, etc. Any ideas? I'm perplexed because the S controllers are under a year old and the original controller has been in use since the end of 2015 and has seen a ton of headset time.

Yep. Tried both of them about 10 times each with no change in results. Did it both ways, headset connected, headset disconnected. The Xbox doesn't even pick up that a headset is connected with the S controllers. If I plug in with the original controller, the mute icon goes away and the headset icon appears. With the S controllers the mute icon stays.

Just two, the newest ones that have only been in service since Christmas and only saw the headphone use the one day my son used them this summer. I bought the two remote One S Xbox setup at Costco last holiday season, so hopefully I can find my remote since Costco is good about exchanging stuff and warranties.

Keystone Lake near Tulsa, OK. This was in the late 1980's. Bouyed off swimming area in a cove. I was about 10-11 at the time. Waded out until I could BARELY touch the bottom. Then couldn't. Thought I'd shoot for the other side. Less than halfway there realized I was in trouble. Trying to keep my head up, gulping water with air. Swim underwater, then try to paddle with my head up. I started freaking out mentally and there was no one close. At the point when I started to give up and realize the morbidity of my mistake, my foot grazed the bottom. I walked a LONG way around to the side I came from. Get back and all my dad said was "decided to walk back huh? You looked like you were in trouble out there.". Thanks Pop. I've held a disdain for my father and a fear of drowning ever since.

WRITING.TITLE: Ok, so I am a big Tony Romo fan...........But...........
WRITING.TEXT: After seeing the Carson Wentz news today (broken bone in back, apparently out the rest of the season), I want nothing more than to have a pic or a meme with Romo's head on Wentz's body in uniform so I can shove it at all my Eagles fan buddies after all the crap they blew towards me as a Cowboys fan for years. Anyone else feel that way? *Edit* Ok, I'll clarify some things. I'm not rooting for an injury and I'm not belittling Wentz (he's a hell of a QB, personally I'd prefer to have him over Dak but I'd FAR rather see Romo behind center still) nor do I harbor any ill will for the guy. I lived outside Philly for a few years and a few of my good friends are DIE HARD Philly fans. For years I got beat up about Romo being hurt as much as he was. It was all good natured, no one was rooting for someone to get hurt or anything, but if/when it happened, here came the trolling. Saying what I said above was not meant in any mean way at all, but would be the same firing back that I took from my friends. That's all. It's a good natured rivalry we have. We all get that no one wants to see anyone get hurt, have a career ruined, etc.

With that kind of a commute driving solo a 2015 TDi Sportwagen would come close to tripling your fuel economy (we get 49 highway with two adults, two kids, two dogs, and luggage). A 2009-2014 would give you slightly less but still mud to upper 40's. Not to mention once you move your resale value would be much better in terms of losses if you decide to move on. *Edit* I will add that while it is a wagon, it's not a huge car. It's narrow, and not overly long. I have fit an 8' piece of baseboard in, but nothing longer is going to fit as it was hatch to windshield. So do factor that into your purchase. They WILL tow, so you could get a small utility trailer and made do that way.
What would 47mpg do to your estimate. You'll likely be in that range at 65-70 MPH.

Motors will last about forever. Turbos in the 200k range give or take. Other stuff is normal failure rates like other vehicles. DPF could be a costly fix but should be covered by dieselgate warranty for some time. Speaking of, if you want good warranty, a 2015 is THE way to go. The expansive dieselgate warranty covers the GREATER of 11 years or 162k miles from original in service date. For a 2015 Sportwagen with lowish miles, probably the 12-14k range for a S or SE model. 09-14 probably 10k ish range. Those are rough guesstimates. We bought our 15 GSW SEL with 32k miles in October 17 for $18.5k and I felt that was a good deal. Something else to consider if you're a DIY guy.....oil change interval is 10k miles. DSG (trans) service is 40k. Timing belt is 130k and a very easy straight forward job.

No issues with the manuals. I'd prefer to have manuals but my Passat SEL wasn't available equipped as such and my wife preferred an auto for her GSW. Finding the right car can be a task. You may end up travelling a few hours, but you'll know when the right car appears. Just keep searching and it'll show up. Now that the whole dieselgate thing is winding down, they're becoming more and more prevalent. With autotrader, search by fuel type. That always got my best results when I was looking. If I searched for submodel-tdi I got far less results. But filtering fuel type to diesel opened it up.

WRITING.TITLE: Good Thinking Microsoft!!
WRITING.TEXT: I just had to say thanks somewhere. I have two kids who got original black XBox One's for Christmas this year (my old one and a used one we picked up). It's something that occurred to me, and we'll further engage as time passes if we find other games we like playing together on.

I'd think you can get into a 15 S model for the 12-13K price range. When I was looking in the Fall of 2017 for one I was finding S and SE's in the 14-15K range. A quick browse of AutoTrader and I found a BUNCH of 15's with under 30K miles for $12-13K. I'd advise for a 2015 also because if you get a low mileage one, the dieselgate warranty is top notch. Greater of 11 Years / 162K miles from original service date OR 5 years / 60K miles from Phase 1 and then Phase 2 of fix, and Covers pretty much everything motor/emissions related (fuel system, turbo, OBD codes/repairs, exhaust, DEF system, DPF, etc) for that period. The 11-14's don't get near the warranty. Plus the 15's are more fuel efficient and look better. Life expectancy? Taken care of, how long do you want to keep it? Because it'll last you that long. *Edited to correct warrant limit info.

WRITING.TITLE: I have been missing out
WRITING.TEXT: This past year I replaced my living room and bedroom TV's with a 65 and 55 LG B7A respectively. A tremendous upgrade from the get go. I run a Plex server at home and all my local movies are clean and slightly compressed 1080 Blu Ray rips. A few months back I discovered I had a 4k friendly drive for my computer so I could start ripping 4K but haven't due to knowing how much space it would command, and there was no way to compress the huge files without losing HDR and killing the visual properties. Until yesterday. I repurposed a 3tb hard drive as an experiment, ripped a few 4k movies and threw them on it. I needed to check for latency as this drive is stored remote to my plex server, and I needed to see if my home network (Orbi) would be up to the task of streaming uncompressed 4k material. I'm pleased to say that both are good to go and other than needing to get a couple of larger drives (Transformers Last Knight was 90gb for example) I'm more than happy with the result. Visually......it's just stunning. Movies I've seen before and like are mind blowingly different, so much better now. My mind is just blown as how much better the 4k HDR stuff is over it's Blu Ray counterpart.
Woah. Thanks for the clarification. I kind of figured there was some kind of compression going on, but didn't realize that uncompressed it was THAT kind of size.
Mainly because I prefer to keep things digitized. Little hands like getting into things and it's way more convenient. I had just been digitizing the Blu Ray 1080 copies and living with that.
Ha. My bandwidth limit says no.

I have done just this. Here's what I was working with and I love it (though I'm about to condense into a single computer due to space constraints): I7 950 Processor Asus Rampage III Gene Motherboard Some teeny GPU for when I need to actually be in the computer on a display (I remote in majority of the time) 6GB DDR3 Ram (was tri channel) Samsung Evo 512GB SSD for OS Windows 7 Ultimate Dell PERC H700 Raid Card (these are available literally for $20-30 now, add about $15 worth of Mini-Sas to SATA breakout cables, and you're golden) 8x HGST Ultrastar 7k3000 3TB Hard Drives, 2 VD's of 4 drives in RAID 5. I bought every last one as a data center pull refurb for $50 each. Been running 24/7 for over two years now. These are enterprise drives rated for 24/7 operation and are a steal. I've had a single drive die. I got an email, went in and took it off line, replaced a few days later with another drive, rebuild took almost 24 hours, back up and fully running. The Hardware RAID is instrumental to me, I won't stray from it. Works like a champ. Runs 24/7, streams plex fine for me (most of my devices direct stream everything, even my 4k stuff), runs QBittorrent and Sonarr 24/7 flawlessly also. ZERO issues. I have it hooked up to a 1080 HDTV in my office so I can actually watch whatever while I'm working on my main PC doing other things. Current plan is to migrate everything on the above over to my main computer (I7-5820K, EVGA X99 Micro 2, 32gb DDR4, 512 GB Samsung 960 Pro M.2, Fractal Node 804 case) with the addition of another H700 and 10TB drives, 4 to start with and add more as necessary. The 4K stuff takes up a TON of space because I don't compress it. But I only have about 8.5 TB of movies and shows currently. I figure this way I can condense to a single computer as a 24/7 box that will do what I currently have two separate computers doing.

I would want verification that the rebuilt LT4 is exactly that. Externally it's very hard to tell the difference between an LT1 or LT4 considering the LT4 manifold fits the LT1 with machining and the LT1 manifold is easily painter or powder coated red. Look for the casting numbers on the heads and manifold and verify they are legit LT4 parts. Also, if it is an automatic, it's not an LT4 car. ONLY 1996 Manuals and Grand Sports got the LT4. *Edit* Just saw you said it's a six speed. No worries there then.

WRITING.TITLE: Houston......we have a problem.......
WRITING.TEXT: DISCLAIMER: This is purely for fun, I'm not looking for assistance or anything. Just thought I'd have some amusement with my plight...... Check engine light popped up on my 2012 Passat this morning on the way to work. Symptoms? Other than a nagging cold engine nailing and 1800RPM light throttle input hesitation/stumble, nothing. Any guesses? I'll update later when I get home and get VAGCOM hooked up to it. Here's the update as of 1926 EST: "8845 - Torque Difference Cylinder 4 // P1007 00 [096] - Limit Value Exceeded // Intermittent - Not Confirmed - Tested Since Memory Clear" This is NOT what set the CEL but I'm extremely happy it's showing up because it helps confirm the running issues I was experiencing when the motor is cold. What follows is what set it off: "18638 - NOx Sensor 1 Bank 1 // P2201 00 [236] - Implausible Signal // MIL ON - Intermittent - Confirmed - Tested Since Memory Clear // Freeze Frame: (I'm not typing all that out)." Also had: "15733 - SCR NOx Catalyst Bank 1 // P20EE 00 [096] - Efficiency too low // Intermittent = Not Confirmed - Tested Since Memory Clear" Now it's just a matter of getting the dealer to address the two NON-MIL setting issues when they take care of the NOx Sensor (that was strangely enough replaced about 40K ago I believe).

It's already had all the AdBlue heater fixes. I doubt it's that but you never know. I'm PRAYING it's something injector related. I've been chasing a sticky when cold injector (at least that's what I think and what symptoms point to) since last winter and my dealership refuses to actually diagnose it saying "we can't really look for anything if there's no check engine light."
I get off work at 6 and won't be home until near 7 but it's my first order of business upon arrival.

WRITING.TITLE: Dealership Unwilling To Do Their Job -- Advice Needed
WRITING.TEXT: My 2012 Passat hasn't been right since winter of 2017-2018. When the motor is cold I get BAD nailing sounds, what feels like a dead cylinder at about 1800 RPM under light throttle, and I've seen reduced fuel economy since the first indications. NEVER a check engine light though. Took it to the dealership around this time last year, they kept the car for a couple of days, tech said nothing is wrong, can't duplicate, I took him out in the car and showed him what it's doing, and I got the brush off of "if there's no MIL we really can't do anything." I dealt with it. Fast forward to last week. My MIL finally pops on. I run a pull with VCDS and get the following: 8845 - Torque Difference Cylinder 4 P1007 00 [096] - Limit Value Exceeded Intermittent - Not Confirmed - Tested Since Memory Clear 18638 - NOx Sensor 1 Bank 1 P2201 00 [236] - Implausible Signal MIL ON - Intermittent - Confirmed - Tested Since Memory Clear Freeze Frame (not entering, not necessary) 15733 - SCR NOx Catalyst Bank 1 P20EE 00 [096] - Efficiency too Low Intermittent - Not Confirmed - Tested Since Memory Clear So I take the car into the dealer. The put a new NOx sensor in, cleared up the MIL, did a couple of recalls, and that's that. While I was dropping it off I was describing the driveability issues to the writer and explaining the nailing and dead cylinder feel to the adviser and the tech behind her, same guy as last time, said "that's normal for warm up." I explained to him NO, that's NOT normal, I've had the car for 3 1/2 years and over 50K miles and I only started experiencing it last year. He brushed me off. Got called today that the car is done. Spoke with the adviser again and we went over notes. When I dropped it off, I explained to not be alarmed, I do my own non-warranty service and just in November did an Oil Change, DSG Service, Timing Belt w/Water Pump, and filters (Fuel, Air, Cabin). I asked if the two pending codes were addressed. She said "we can't address those because they don't show up on our software and they're not even VW codes." Finding that rather incredulous, I pressed further but got nowhere. I asked did they look at anything other than the NOx sensor. She said her tech noted in the system that "no oil change sticker on dash, question type of oil used, recommend oil change and recheck vehicle for driveability." Essentially at this point I'm feeling this dealership is treating me like I'm clueless (the "that's normal for warm up" and snarky oil change note in the system), and isn't doing a single thing to address issues that I've brought up (that are most likely a failing injector), and using every excuse they can to get out of even attempting to actually troubleshoot an issue. I'm not sure which way to go from here. This is the ONLY VW dealership in my area other than an unrelated Audi dealer in town where I'm not sure how much help I'd get. I'm contemplating a VWOA phone call but not sure that'll get me anything. *edit* Formatting
I have road tested with the Technician. He tried telling me that he doesn't hear anything and the stumble and shuddering is normal. It's not.

Closest dealerships are about an hour and a half away. This is literally the only one around. It wouldn't be me paying for it unless it was a part not covered by the warranty (which it very likely is covered). Hence my feeling they're trying to just move me along so they don't have to deal with it. Picking up my car tomorrow morning, going to have a few words with the warranty advisor at the dealership.

WRITING.TITLE: Nothing like a cheap Projector to get your home theater setup started.......
WRITING.TEXT: So.......being the good friend that I am, I purchased a Mitsubishi HC3800 projector off my buddy who decided he wanted to upgrade to a 4K unit rather than deal with aftermarket bulbs (it is saying it's near EOL on the bulb). So for $100, I said why not. I have a framed and insulated basement, to which I have a room that I think may work. It's 11' wide by 14.5' long. Entry door at the rear left, small half height opening at the front left for under stairs cubby where I plan to have A/V stuff residing, possibly installed in-wall for easier access. Ceilings are about 8' 8" tall with the rear of the room having an HVAC duct set lowering it to just over 8' height. Projector is planned for installation either directly under the ducting, or just in front of the drop for it, throwing on the 11' wide front wall. The ONLY other equipment I have at this point is my trusty old Infinity IL50 tower speakers which will continue to serve as my front channel and two subs. So........I have questions, and I have thoughts. Is this too small of a room to try to pull off a 7.1 setup? That's about the max I'd want to try, I am not interested in attempting anything more than that. Am I wrong in thinking that the rear channels will need to be slightly behind the sitting position? If that's the case then I'm going to have to figure some kind of layout setup for the room also because we're a family of four and 11' isn't too terribly wide. I'm obviously going to wire everything in-wall, using wall plates for quick connections, etc. I'm going to make a single HDMI run to the projector, and am going to ensure it's high enough grade to ensure I can upgrade to 4K if I want down the road. I'm looking on layout suggestions, seating/layout suggestions, lighting suggestions, etc. This room is studded and insulated, and the only negative I really have is my fuse box is in this room also, and I'm worried about it rattling but that can be mitigated. Just looking for thoughts and ideas mainly! Thanks!

That's either a 92 or 93 LT1, accessory drive setup says it's from a Corvette. Lack of a MAF is a dead giveaway as is the lack of a front fuel rail crossover recess in the intake manifold. This is run off of a Speed Density ECM, and utilizes a PROM chip instead of a reflashable ECM. It's also a Batch Fired injector setup, not the sequential fired setup of the 94-97 LT1's. The motor itself is essentially the same between the years, but the computer and logic of the early 92-93 ones is quite different. You're also likely to find an unvented optispark with a spline drive unless it's been converted to the later style cam dowel pin driven unit with the vents, which was a pretty common swap (I did it to two 93 Trans Am's myself). If you want to search parts for the motor, a 92 or 93 Corvette would be your best bet. The F-Body used an accessory drive setup that put the alternator on the other side (passenger side) of the motor. That's definitely a Corvette setup.

Well that's totally subjective. To add some clarification: Reverse flow cooling meaning coolant flows through the heads first. This is an added bonus and not a detractor. Keeps chamber temps and hot spots down, allowing more aggressive compression ratios and timing curves. Nothing negative to be had. EGR? Kludged together? I see this as a non issue. Stricter emissions requirements propagate added hardware, things like some extra tubes and an air injection pump. Guess what? The L98 got that stuff too. The LT engine bay on the Vette is no worse than the L98. You compared F-Bodies. That's a stark contrast on those cars because as the engine evolved so did the chassis of the car which is where your feelings of it being easier to work on come from, as the 4th gen chassis is much tighter around the motor, not to mention the rear half of the engine sits under the cowl. The Corvette on the other hand doesn't suffer from those changes. Ignition system. Ok, the L98 gets the not from me because of reliability. The optispark in the LTx is a fantastic piece of engineering, poorly executed. Under the water pump?!?! Brilliant idea. But......they are tremendously accurate and when they are working it's hard to beat them. In terms of sheer performance, L98 lt; LT1/4 lt; LS1/2/6/7/3 lt; LT1/4. It's just simple evolution. But because one car doesn't have the performance of another doesn't mean it's not worth it to someone. Look at it from a Corvette perspective and not a performance enthusiast perspective. Each and every one has it's attributes. For the OP........don't let other people's opinions sway you from what YOU want. That car obviously has sentimental value. From what you've said and what was posted here, people are focusing on one thing mainly. How much power does it make? There's SO much more to it than that. Just because it's not going to make 400 RWHP with mods doesn't mean it's not worth it. It's all in what you want and will be happy with. From the sounds of it, your family has an attachment to this particular car. Get it and don't let anyone talk you out of it. *Edit - correcting autocorrect

I ask you this: Do you want a Corvette for the driving experience and to build up and modify for more performance, or do you want this particular 1991 Corvette because of the family ties. If the former, look for something newer/more capable. If the latter, buy it back and never think twice.

WRITING.TEXT: So this was made in September of 2016........the last day my car moved. This is my youngest son, and my oldest got a ride immediately afterwards. Reason the car got torn into was after both blasts it dropped oil pressure before recovering (classic sticking check valve in the pump). My youngest here was just over 3.....he's 5 1/2 now and was asking me this morning to see the video and when he can ride in my "Fast blue car" again. For what it's worth, the new heads are on, cam is in, front cover is back on.....I need to fix an oxygen sensor harness so I can put the turbo's/manifolds/downpipes back in, then it's all downhill. Absolutely necessary? No. But......yes, you would benefit from that. Even without headers, you've changed the VE of the motor enough that a tune would net you some power and economy. The Speed Density logic (No MAF or Mass Airflow Sensor) ECM used on the early 90's cars will adapt to a degree, but it's capability is quickly overrun. Not to mention the factory tunes are pretty conservative on these. Do you need to dyno tune it? No. Downvote me if you will everyone, but it's not necessary for the simple bolt on's as mentioned above. OP what you need to do is find someone familiar with the early 90's stuff. I did a lot of tuning work a long time back in the mid 2000's with a guy down in NC who used to be a part of PCMForLess and split off. He was the go to guy for speed density tuning, and he still does it under his grown into shop called PCMofNC. My recommendation would be send his shop an email and see what he can do for you.

WRITING.TITLE: Something simple to make a kitchen feel a little more modern.....
WRITING.TEXT: Concealed soft close cabinet hinges and soft close drawer slides. What a doggone improvement it made on my dated 1998 builder grade kitchen (laminate countertops, pecan stained oak cabinets, cheap plastic hinges, cheapest drawer slides available). And it's SO SIMPLE. Kreg jig for $30 is worth every cent. I used a combination of Blum and Grass euro style (35mm) soft close hinges due to my narrow 1/4" overlay (which Blum only had a press in hinge for). A 10 pack of either is about $35. As for the drawer slides, there are a LOT of options out there. What I found was you want to select a manufacturer who uses metal pins, not plastic. I can get 10 pair of 22" slides from Gobrico on Amazon for $125ish, and they have held up great so far. Plus they're black so they look pretty nice. Best part about this is that you can slowly work on these simple but effective updates as funds or time allows. You can buy by the pair, or in bulk, there's tons of options available. But when you've got a dated kitchen or something and you want to do just a little something to improve it, this is a relatively inexpensive and quick way to make that progress.
