Hmmm.......try this (I had to dig, it's been a while since I've owned a running LT1 car): 1 - Disconnect the IAC harness connector 2 - Turn on the key. This will put the IAC into "reset mode". 3 - Turn off the key and reconnect the IAC harness 4 - VERY LIGHTLY holding the throttle ever so slightly open, start the car. This will reset the IAC. Run for 5-10 seconds. 5 - Turn off the car and release the gas. 6 - Restart and test drive to see if things went back to normal.

Ok, gonna put my flame suit on here because there's bound to be the inevitable haters. Zaino. It's the ONLY polish product I use on my 99 Nassau Blue C5 UNLESS I'm doing a machine polish, in which case I personally prefer Menzerna products (SIP, IP, and FP). But even then, my final polish is hand applied Zaino. It's somewhat spendy (will cost you about $75 starting from scratch), but it goes a LONG way as you apply it very VERY lightly. The key is in the prep. The better base you start with, the better the results. It's also a multi-step process and an all day thing. BUT......it lasts FOREVER, and layers so once you have that base coat down, a wash is SUPER fast, and you can apply another coat very quickly after that and get better results. Just my $.02. Everyone will have their preferences, Zaino just happens to be mine.

2019-05-11 03:29:22
Ok, I was just doing some research because to my knowledge the "Delco/Mongoose" package wasn't a factory authorized package, but aftermarket through Corvette Concepts and available in several stages with HP ratings up to about 425 (Stage IV 425SS is the highest I can find). Through some more research, I found the CL ad for this car. The name Ron Bilyeu checks out associated with "Pro Auto Tech" back then who originated the Mongoose packages which were continued by Corvette Concepts. Some more information showed me that up to the 425SS were simply bolt on's and additional packages involving head/cam swaps were available to about a 490 HP rating (flywheel). This is just finding bits and pieces here and there since neither company seems to exist anymore and the majority of the info is gone. But. What REALLY concerns me, is though you may have snagged this car for a pretty cheap deal, don't expect it to give you what the CL ad said. There is ZERO way that car was making 500 RWHP. That engine has original 97-98 853 heads, the perimeter bolts for the valve covers are a dead giveaway. Those heads won't support that power. The claim of a 427 LS1 is pretty far fetched also, considering the Darton Sleeve kit for those engines until the early 2000's. Even then, IF it's been sleeved and stroked out to a 427 (4.125 bore / 4.000 stroke), those heads still aren't going to support 500 to the tires. Looking at all the pics and info on the car, I'm afraid you bought yourself into a super bad money pit that may never be sorted correctly. It's going to take a LOT of money to put that car back to road worthiness. Not trying to be a debbie downer, but just giving an honest opinion.

2019-05-28 23:18:11
I'm going to cover some stuff that's already been covered, but here goes: 91 -- Last of the L98 TPI 350 cars. First year of the exterior facelift. Motor is typical SBC based, but is limited in terms of power output. 92-93 -- LT1, speed density based ECU (no MAF) that uses a chip. OBNOXIOUS to tune, mainly because competent speed density chip burning tuners are few and far between anymore. 94-96 -- LT1, MAF based PCM and flashable, no chips. 96 LT4 on the CE and M6 models only. LT4 was a better set of slightly raised runner heads and a more aggressive cam profile. The LT4 cars will run just behind a stock C5, but like the rest of the LT1's, runs out of steam up top still. Optisparks are NOT bad units. Cheap ones are. Genuine Delco ones are usually pretty solid. The optical sensor was originally a Mitsubishi in the OEM Delco Opti's. Even those are some non-mitsu vendor now however. Opti's are one of the most accurate distributors ever designed, with a full 360 degree slotted disc providing accuracy down to 1 degree. The 92-94 cars saw a spline driven non-vented unit, while the 95-96 cars got the much easier to install redesigned cam dowel driven vented units. A big pitfall of the LT1 and (and opti) was it's execution. Let's put the opti right under the freaking water pump. Guess what happens when your water pump goes out? Your opti takes a coolant bath because the weep hole for the pump is DIRECTLY over the opti. They're really not that bad though. I owned twos LT1 cars from 2000 until 2015 and only ever had two opti's die. They're not that terrible to replace either, just irritating because you have to take off the water pump. Now.......I'll say this. EFI Connections 24X. Ditches the opti, goes to Coil over plug like the LS motors, easy enough to install, but a little costly (about $2200 if you purchase everything, a LOT cheaper if you repin your harness yourself and source other parts separately). As for other aspects.........The ZF6 has got to be one of the smoothest manual transmissions I've ever had the privilege of driving. Absolutely a dream to be in control of. The C4's are raw, and you feel like you're in a fighter jet in them because of the seating position and design (can confirm, I've got seat time in an F-16). Personally, my recommendation would be to look for a 95-96 car, preferably a 96 LT4 car as it's just the best you could get in an C4. But if you find the right car, you'll just know, so keep an eye on all the years (91 for example was the last year you could get the AWESOME Steel Blue Metallic color).

2019-05-28 23:20:49
The LS3 in the 08 is a pretty big step forward from the LS2 in the 07. The 2008 also saw the debut of the TR6060 transmission, a much more stout evolution from the T56 that was still in the 2007. The 2007 isn't a bad car per se, and at the right price can be an excellent buy. But if you're side by side pro's vs con's, the 07 compared to an 08 has two big strikes against it.

2019-06-22 16:29:32
Long Post Coming. TL/DR: A lot of expensive shit. This build was the result of a couple of things. One, the oil pump check valve started sticking, and as such, necessitated opening the motor up. Two, there was a lot simply wrong with the car after I had repurchased it from the gentleman I'd sold it to (his guy doing the work was a freaking hack job). I wanted to bring the car back up to my personal standards hence the detail and minor things you've seen me clean up along the way. So what went into the car this time? The meat of the stuff was top end related due to a couple times the motor pushed water. Tony Mamo 235 NFI Heads w/machining for YT 10mm Rockers Yella Terra 10mm Rocker Package (came with heads) Tony Mamo Custom Camshaft ATI Balancer built to Mamo's Spec Tony Mamo ported Melling 10296 Oil Pump Johnson 2116LSR Limited Travel Link Bar Lifters Manton Custom Length 3 Piece 11/32 thick wall pushrods Tony Mamo Ported LS2 Manifold and 90mm Throttlebody Additional things done while this was apart was fixing some shoddy wiring, completely redoing the vacuum distribution setup, correctly plumbing in the blow off valves, adding a vented breather tank and removing the factory PCV setup and catch can (she'd get a little smokey over about 14-15 PSI boost). Stepped backwards to a 97-98 return style fuel system from a billet rail/-an line setup. Stepped backwards from a FAST 102/NW 102 setup to the LS2 setup. The backwards steps were to keep thing clean and factory looking. The rest of the car is as follows: Texas Speed 377 forged LS3 Short Block APS Twin Turbo system with LG Motorsports upgraded 70lb/min turbo's Turbosmart Kompact BOV's Lonnies Performance Double Pumper fuel system 2008 C6Z TR6060 Trans, Diff, rear cradle setup Ram Twin Disc Clutch CCW SP500 Wheels C6Z Brakes, translucent copper powdercoated, with Racing Brake 2 piece front and rear rotors I'm probably forgetting a whole lot of smaller things. Was making about 825-850 RWHP before. When I sold it back in 2010 it was making a solid repeatable 761/760 to the wheels with the factory turbo's. It came back to me with the upgraded turbo's, 102 stuff, and C6Z driveline in 2015. Now, I'm going to see what it can do on the factory 97-98 fuel lines/rail setup. At 761/760 it had PLENTY of head room on 80lb injectors (it has 95's now). I'd like to see 1K RWHP or better........but I'm going to be happy with it running safely and expect it to be solidly in the 900's. It's a LOT of money to spend for an extra 100-200 RWHP, but I also look at it as a longevity thing because the parts are FAR better than what was taken off the car.

2019-07-13 09:20:47
To get it up to par with a C5, in terms of power, you'll need an aftermarket intake and a header back exhaust setup, throw in a 160* thermostat and a tune, and that should put you very close to 300 RWHP. You're going to spend about $1500 give or take to get there. The unfortunate part is the C4 is going to show it's age. It's an older platform, and the C5 was a HUGE leap forward in terms of engineering design (it's stiffer but rides better, more comfortable, easier to get in and out of, etc). I'm NOT ragging on the C4.....the C5 is just better. Biggest gotcha with the C4 is the distributor can be troublesome (search optispark, and take it with a grain of salt because of the squeaky wheel curve). After that, it's essentially a Gen 1 Small Block Chevy motor with reverse cooling and aluminum heads. Unfortunately that means it's going to be power limited if you start tearing into it. It WILL take a full head and cam package to reach 400 RWHP where as a LS1 will do it cam only. In the end, it's your call. You have to decide if a C4 is for you, or you want to hold out for the C5. Depending on what you'd be trading (what is it, I'm curious), you could try on the C4, then sell if it's not for you as the C4 market seems to be recovering.

All my fears put to rest (the car was NEVER fired up before it went to him, and I was unsure of myself and the work I did). Car runs, moves under it's own power, initial boost results on wastegate ONLY (no boost controller input, no methanol) were 803/728 at the wheels. He said other than the two problems listed below the car is perfect. Faith in myself restored. Bad news. Starter died, methanol tank leaking. I've ordered a new meth pump and tank seals, and am going to try to get the car home tomorrow to replace the starter. Gotta go back later to finish tuning under boost at about 18-20lbs. Really encouraged by breaking 800 RWHP at only 12 PSI. ESPECIALLY considering this isn't a cobbled together fender exhaust car. This is a full weight street car, the ONLY factory option I no longer have is the F45 shocks because the turbo pipes went right through the sensor arm. I'm really hopeful if my fuel system holds up it'll crack 1000 RWHP before seeing 20lbs of boost. More to come........

1. Ten year old tires can be unsafe. They may look fine, but rubber degradation and component separation ARE a thing, though they may not manifest visibly until failure. Source: I work for one of the biggest names in the tire industry as part of their quality group. 2. Even if it's an old tire, if it's structurally sound (you were driving on it and drove it in), nothing about the dismounting process should damage a tire under normal circumstances. Source: I was an auto tech for years and have done this job numerous times. 3. They're feeding you some serious ganja if they want you to believe it costs $120 to mount and balance two tires. See source for #2. Typical M amp;B cost is about $20 per tire at any tire shop. Frankly, old tire or not, it came into the shop in one piece, and it should leave the same. If they damaged it, that's on them, and their dime, to make it right. I would advise replacing the 10 year old tires for sure (check the 4 digit date stamp at the end of the DOT code on the tire. Only one side will have the date code stamp. Four digits, representing week and year of production). But in this situation, for the front tire they damaged, culpability remains with the shop.

Some more tinkering, then boom, that starter broke. Pulled the plugs and found that the motor was hydrolocked. METHANOL. Something in my meth injection system, likely the pump because it was VERY old and leaking heavily from the head, failed, and it kept running after the last dyno pull. This was discovered yesterday. I was absolutely beside myself. Got home, couldn't take it, so I went out and got a new starter (third one) and replaced it, then compression tested the motor. Came back good surprisingly. 2019-09-14 13:55:14
The BIGGEST thing you need to look for on a potential purchase of a C5 (anything with an LS motor actually) is front crank pulley wobble. There are an outer ring and an inner hub bonded with a rubber insulator between them that degrades over time and the two metal pieces begin to separate. This causes the pulley to wobble, and causes anything from belt chirping up to throwing the belts. It's an involved replacement given the steering rack is directly in front of the pulley (books around 4.5 hours for the job). Besides that, they're solid cars. Yeah, they're 20 years old, so expect a little blemish or problem here or there, but there's not a lot of electronics on them to go bad, you're not going to find rust everywhere, etc. Even a wobbling balancer wouldn't be enough to make me walk away from a good buy. The motors/trans/drivelines are all solid on these cars and hold up great if taken care of.

I have a 2012 SEL with just over 148K miles on it. Have owned it for the last 4 years and 56K miles. It's been a wonderful car. Even post fix I get 48-50 MPG highway only. I've done all my own maintenance (including timing belt) with exception to warranty work. I've had ONE issue where a fuel line under the car spontaneously disconnected that left me seeking a tow. Other than that it's been solid. I take as good of care as I can with it, but I am getting ready to have a door repainted and the hood replaced courtesy of VW and it's rust warranty. The bottom edge of my rear passenger door started bubbling, and I had some minor rust starting on the UNDERSIDE front of my hood. Even my dealer who looked at it said "that's odd, those are both really weird spots." Just follow your maintenance schedule and you'll be fine. And rest assured you've got a pretty solid warranty behind it too.

Been chasing my tail on this oil leak......
2019-09-21 03:59:30
Reddit post
2019-09-21 04:04:47
Noticed it Wednesday night, found a big puddle on my garage floor. I'd only driven the car home from my buddies on Saturday then run it shortly for the kids amusement on Wednesday evening. Traced it to the valve cover but couldn't figure out WHY it was leaking given the Yella Terra 5132 thick gaskets on OEM covers. Threw some permatex grey on the sealing surface and let it sit last night. Figured out how to get my gopro to see the area it was leaking from. MUCH to my surprise I found the cause. That gold bracket for my turbo oil distribution block was designed around factory height valve covers. The extra 5/16 height given by the thick YT gaskets was enough to cause just enough interference for the cover to leak. I would still be chasing my tail had not put my GoPro where I did because I can't see the interference from the top side.

2019-09-24 20:31:47
Make sure you know what you're getting into if you're purchasing an already modded car. You don't want to buy into someone's pieced together undocumented car because if a problem crops up, you're going to be doing a lot of guesswork. So for an STS rear mount turbo setup.......not a lot of extra maintenance. Stay on top of oil changes, keep an eye on your scavenge pump, ensure it's got a catch can and some kind of PCV modification (breather and/or a check valve so you don't pressurize the crank case under boost). Being a turbo setup, it'll drive like stock if you keep your foot out of it. Reliability is a relative term. Forced induction isn't necessarily something you think of when you think long term reliability. Be prepared for things to break if you're driving it hard. When you start adding power via FI, you start finding weak spots, fixing them, then finding the next weak spot.
